derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English slōh, slō(g), of unknown origin
Middle English (as a noun denoting a skin, especially the outer skin shed by a snake): perhaps related to Low German slu(we) 'husk, peel'. The verb dates from the early 18th cent

entry.def: When a plant sloughs its leaves, or an animal such as a snake sloughs its skin, the leaves or skin come off naturally.

example.ex: All reptiles have to slough their skin to grow...
example.tran: 所有爬行动物生长过程中都要蜕皮。

example.ex: The lemon geranium sloughs dry brown leaves at the base of its branches.
example.tran: 柠檬天竺葵枝条底部棕色的枯叶会脱落。

means.word_mean: 1. necrotic tissue; a mortified or gangrenous part or mass
3. a stagnant swamp (especially as part of a bayou)
4. any outer covering that can be shed or cast off (such as the cast-off skin of a snake)
1. cast off hair, skin, horn, or feathers;
